title: Results
text:
Significantly higher lung cancer mortality in East Portland and significantly lower lung cancer mortality in Northwest and Southwest Portland.
No significant difference in breast cancer or pancreatic cancer by geographic area.
Data was too limited/variable to conclusively analyze trends over time.
There are limitations to our data set that likely resulted in underestimates of the true mortality rates.

title: Results
text:
Significantly higher lung cancer mortality in East Portland and significantly lower lung cancer mortality in Northwest and Southwest Portland.
No significant difference in breast cancer or pancreatic cancer by geographic area.
Data was too limited/variable to conclusively analyze trends over time.
There are limitations to our data set that likely resulted in underestimates of the true mortality rates.

title: Results
text:
Maps


`nframes` and `fps` adjusted to match transition











`nframes` and `fps` adjusted to match transition











`nframes` and `fps` adjusted to match transition










Results of Statistical Tests
One way ANOVA tests revealed no significant differences in the average mortality rates of breast cancer or pancreatic cancer based on geography (p > 0.05).
Geographic area did have an impact on lung cancer mortality (p = 0.000004). Tukey’s HSD pairwise comparisons revealed that East Portland had significantly higher lung cancer mortality rates compared to the North & Northeast (11.58 rate difference, p = 0.005), Central East (11.69 rate difference, p = 0.0045), and Northwest & Southwest (18.95 rate difference, p = 0.0000012) areas. Additionally, Northwest & Southwest Portland had significantly lower rates than the areas of East Portland (18.95 rate difference, p = 0.0000012), Southeast Portland (12.73 rate difference, p = 0.0015), and Gresham & Troutdale cities (11.65 rate difference, p = 0.0047).


Limitations
There are significant limitations to our findings. Our analysis did not adjust for demographic factors that impact cancer mortality, such as race, gender, age, occupation, or smoker status. This is especially relevant for breast cancer mortality rates which were not restricted to the female population as is the convention in public health. Additionally, our dataset only includes ten years of data, making it limited for drawing conclusions regarding the impact of environmental factors currently impacting Multnomah County residents, many of which can take decades of data to draw strong conclusions about their impact. Regarding the quality of our dataset, approximately 20% of observations were dropped due to missing or incorrect FIPS codes leading to underestimates of true mortality rates.

title: Background Information
text:
Cancer Type
National Average Mortality Rate/100k Population




Lung
31.5


Breast
19.2


Pancreas
11.3




Genetic predisposition, social determinants, and environmental hazards all impact a person’s likelihood of developing cancer or dying from it.

This analysis focuses on the mortality rates of lung cancer, breast cancer, and pancreatic cancer as these caused the most deaths in Multnomah county over the past decade. Lung cancer is currently the leading cause of cancer death in the United States. According to statistics from the National Cancer Institute’s SEER program, it contributed to 20.1% of all national cancer deaths with a rate of 31.5 deaths per a population of 100,000 men and women. Breast cancer primarily affects women, though it does rarely occur in men. The mortality rate for women is 19.2 per 100,000 women. Pancreatic cancer has a death rate of 11.3 per 100,000.
A combination of biology, social determinants, and physical environment influence the likelihood of cancer outcomes. Risk factors for developing any of these diseases include smoking tobacco products, drinking alcohol, exposure to toxic chemicals, obesity, and genetic predisposition indicated by family history. The chances of developing cancer also increase with age. Looking at cancer rates in the context of geographic location is important as it can reveal the source of carcinogenic environmental pollutants. For example, The Oregon Health Authority’s intervention in a Portland glass manufacturer’s use of cadmium and arsenic reduced the future health risks of nearby residents.


Colditz, G. A., & Wei, E. K. (2012). Preventability of Cancer: The Relative Contributions of Biologic and Social and Physical Environmental Determinants of Cancer Mortality. Annual Review of Public Health, 33(1), 137–156. https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev-publhealth-031811-124627 
Farrer, David G, Dubuisson, Nadège, Karam, Lauren, Hudson, Todd, Sifuentes, Julie, Goldfarb, Gabriela, Environmental Health Assessment Program (Or.), United States Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, (2023) 2023 Public health assessment … release, Bullseye Glass Co. (manufacturing site), 3722 SE 21st Ave, Portland, OR 97202. Retrieved from the Digital Public Library of America, https://digitalcollections.library.oregon.gov/nodes/view/141430 
SEER Cancer Stat Facts: Female Breast Cancer. National Cancer Institute. Bethesda, MD, https://seer.cancer.gov/statfacts/html/breast.html
SEER Cancer Stat Facts: Lung and Bronchus Cancer. National Cancer Institute. Bethesda, MD, https://seer.cancer.gov/statfacts/html/lungb.html
SEER Cancer Stat Facts: Pancreatic Cancer. National Cancer Institute. Bethesda, MD, https://seer.cancer.gov/statfacts/html/pancreas.html

title: Abstract
text:
Abstract
Prevention of cancer mortality is a major public health concern as cancer is the second leading cause of death in the United States. The present study examines the relationship between geographic location and cancer mortality in Multnomah county across the top 3 types of cancer death between 2013 and 2022 using data obtained from the Multnomah County Health Department to answer the research question “How do the top 3 types of cancer death vary by geographic area (public use microdata area) over the past 10 years?”. We calculated cancer mortality rates per 100,000 individuals in the population and created maps to visualize these rates and changes over time. Through one way ANOVA tests and Tukey’s HSD pairwise comparisons conducted in R, we found significantly higher lung cancer mortality in East Portland and significantly lower lung cancer mortality in Northwest and Southwest Portland compared to other studied geographies. This analysis could inform further socioeconomic and demographic research into Multnomah county cancer mortality.

title: Cancer Mortality Rates By Geography In Multnomah County
text:
Cancer Mortality Rates By Geography In Multnomah County
Isabella Moore and Jessica Naworski

title: Methods
text:
This research conducted all data analysis in R.
This research sourced all it’s data from a mortality dataset constructed by the Multnomah county health department
A series of animated maps were made to visually represent cancer mortality rates across Public Use Microdata Area geographies.
One-way Anova and Tukey’s HSD tests were used to determine statistical significance of results.

For data analysis of cancer data by geographic region, all data processing was done in the R coding language with the end goal of producing data tables and other visualizations, including maps and graphs, that accurately report the rates of cancer death across geographies in Multnomah County over ten years. Given the highly sensitive nature of these data, only the aggregate data is available to the public, making many code samples on this page non-functional.


This project utilizes cancer mortality data gathered in Multnomah county between 2013 and 2022. This data was gathered at the individual level, meaning the information in each row of data corresponds to the same individual. This data set contains variables that correspond to date of death, zip code of residence, fips code of residence, age at time of death, sex, marital status, level of education, veteran status, ethnicity and race, occupation, industry of occupation, cause of death, if the death was tobacco related, and comorbidities at time of death. Our project concerns itself with the following variables:

dresstatefips, drescountyfips, drescityfips, ddrestractm and ddrestractsuf: variables relating to the location of death, coded in FIPS code. These variables are critical for determining where cancer moralities are occurring. FIPS codes, or Federal Information Processing Standards codes, are used by the United States Federal Government to ensure consistent data collection across agencies. The smallest units included in these data, FIPS tracts, are drawn so each tract includes a population of approximately 2,500 to 8,000 people and favor boundary lines drawn on physical features such as roads or rivers, but may be drawn on legal boundaries when no physical boundary is available. FIPS tracts were later converted to PUMA, or Public Use Microdata Area codes, which are used within a state to identify geographies with populations of at least 100,000 people and are based on census tracts. PUMA codes were favored over FIPS codes or comparable systems, like ZIP codes, for thier compatibility with data collected in the American Community Survey and data work conducted by the Multnomah County Health Department.
dmcaACME: reports primary cause of death. This variable was used to isolate the top three most common kinds of cancer death. These results were reported as ICD-10 codes, a system used to code health problems across a standardized set of categories. For our analysis, we were only concerned with data relating to the top 3 cancer types
ddodyear: reports year of death. This variable was used to group observations by year and obtain aggregate data for analysis.

Our other major data source was the ACS, or American Community Survey, database. The American Community Survey is an annual survey conducted by the United States Census Bureau to obtain year to year demographic changes in the United States population. These data are not as comprehensive as the full United States Decennial Census, which attempts to gain a complete demography of the country, but are collected more frequently, as the Decennial Census is only completed every ten years while the American Community Survey is conducted annually. Thus, while ACS population data take the form of estimates rather than actual numbers, they are the preferred data source for this project. Our project concerns itself with the following variable:

B01003_001: reports total population estimate by PUMA region. This is later used to calculate rate of mortality by geography.






To transform the raw data into clean aggregate data, manipulation of the data set was completed in R. Numerous packages from the CRAN were downloaded to assist with analysis
The steps taken to clean these data are as follows:

Loaded the data into our coding environment
Concatenated composite FIPS code variables into one FIPS code
Identify the top 3 kinds of cancer death and limit the data to these types
Converted FIPS codes to PUMA codes
Create an aggregated data set of the number of each type of cancer death by year and PUMA code.

The following code chunk includes the code used to create our aggregated data set used for statistical analysis. This code will produce no results, as the data used in it’s non-aggregated form is too sensitive for public use.


Code
#Step 1: load raw data
#rawData <- read_csv() #empty as original .csv file is not publically available


#Step 2: concactenate fips
#create padtract with 4 digits
#withfips <- rawData|> mutate(padtract= str_pad(ddrestract, width = 4, pad = "0"))

# create padtractsuf with 2 digits
#withfips <- withfips|> mutate(padtractsuf = str_pad(ddrestractsuf, width = 2, pad = "0"))

#concactenate into fipscode
#withfips <- withfips|> mutate(fipscode = paste("41051", padtract, padtractsuf, sep = ""))

#remove padded columns
#withfips <- withfips|> select(-padtract, -padtractsuf)


#Step 3: identify and filter data to only include the top 3 types of cancer death
#filter to only c and d icd10 codes
#icdCodes<-read_csv("../multCoData/icd10-codes.csv")

#cancerOnlyData <- withfips |> filter(startsWith(dmcaACME, "C") | startsWith(dmcaACME, "D"))

#cancerOnlyData <-cancerOnlyData |> mutate(diseaseSite=icdCodes$Category[match(dmcaACME, icdCodes$`ICD-10 Code`)])

#cancer10y <- cancerOnlyData|> filter(ddodyear >= 2013)

#Step 4: Convert to PUMA codes
#puma <- read_csv("~/multCoData/2020_Census_Tract_to_2020_PUMA.csv")

#puma <- puma|> filter(STATEFP == 41)

#puma <- puma|> mutate(across(everything(), as.double))

#tidydata <- cancerOnlyData |> left_join(puma, by = c("drescountyfips" = "COUNTYFP", "ddrestract" = "TRACTCE"))

#Step 5: Create an aggregated dataset where independent observations are number of cancer deaths.
#aggregatedData <-cancerOnlyData %>% group_by(ddodyear,diseaseSite,pumaCode) %>% summarise(totals=n())

#prefixAg <- aggregatedData %>% mutate(PUMA = paste("41", pumaCode, sep = ""))

#mutateAg <- prefixAg |> mutate(pumasuffix = sub('^41051', '', PUMA))
#mutateAg <- mutateAg |> mutate(newPUMA = paste("41013", pumasuffix, sep = ""))


This code produces the data set aggregatedData, in which each observation is the number of cancer deaths of a specific type in a specific PUMA region for a specific year between 2013 and 2023. With our data in this form, we can next calculate the rate of mortality by region.



Now that this aggregated data has been assembled with the number of cancer deaths in each region, proportions can be obtained with ACS Data.
The steps taken to form these data are as follows:

Load our new data set into Posit Cloud
Gather total population estimates for each PUMA code across all years
Join the two data sets and derive population proportions by dividing the number of cancer deaths for each cancer type by the total population estimate for that PUMA tract

For this stage of data processing, all analysis was done by year, repeating each code chunk for every year. For the sake of legibility, sample code is only provided for 2013. Wherever the number 2013 is present, it was changed to reflect the accurate year of the data being manipulated


Code
# Step 1: Load the data
#prefixAg <- read_csv("prefixAg.csv", col_types = cols(ddodyear = col_character(),PUMA = col_character()))
#mutateAg <- read_csv("mutateAg.csv", col_types = cols(ddodyear = col_character(), PUMA = col_character(), newPUMA = col_character()))


#Step 2: Gather acs data for each year using tidycensus
#popData2013 <- get_acs(
    #geography = "public use microdata area",
    #variables = c(total_population = "B01003_001"),
    #state = "OR",
    #year = 2013,
    #survey = "acs5",
    #geometry = TRUE, output = "wide") 

#Step 3: Join datasets and derive population porportions
#Ag13 <- mutateAg|> filter(ddodyear == 2013)

#CancerRates2013 <- popData2013 |> right_join(Ag13, by = c("GEOID" = "newPUMA")) |> mutate(rate_per_100k = (totals / total_populationE) * 100000)






The last step in our project was to represent our data visually.


Our primary visualization was a series of maps, grouped by cancer type. These maps visually represent the changing proportions over time.
The steps taken to generate these maps are as follows:

Generate dataframes that consist exclusively of the information needed to create a map
Generate maps based on these dataframes

Sample code for 2013 map generation is shown below


Code
#Step 1: Generates dataframes for map creation
#CancerRatesLung2013 <- CancerRates2013 %>% filter(diseaseSite == "Lung")
#CancerRatesBreast2013 <- CancerRates2013 %>% filter(diseaseSite == "Breast")
#CancerRatesPancreas2013 <- CancerRates2013 %>% filter(diseaseSite == "Pancreas")

# Step 2: Generate maps based on these dataframes
#ggplot(CancerRatesLung2013) + geom_sf(mapping=aes(fill = rate_per_100k)) + scale_fill_viridis_c(name = "Lung Cancer Deaths/100k residents",limits = c(0, 50)) + theme_void() + labs(title="Estimated lung cancer deaths per 100k residents, 2013")

#ggplot(CancerRatesBreast2013) + geom_sf(mapping=aes(fill = rate_per_100k)) +scale_fill_viridis_c(name = "Breast Cancer Deaths/100k residents",limits = c(0, 25)) + theme_void() + labs(title="Estimated breast cancer deaths per 100k residents, 2013")

#ggplot(CancerRatesPancreas2013) + geom_sf(mapping=aes(fill = rate_per_100k)) + scale_fill_viridis_c(name = "Pancreas Cancer Deaths/100k residents",limits = c(0, 20)) + theme_void() + labs(title="Estimated pancreas cancer deaths per 100k residents, 2013")





Our final visualization combined the maps for all ten years into one gif for easier viewing.
The steps taken to generate these maps are as follows:

Combine dataframes that include mortality rates for each year.
Generate maps based on this dataframe with the gganimate package



Code
#Step 1: Combined Dataframe
#CancerRates <- bind_rows(CancerRates2013, CancerRates2014, CancerRates2015, CancerRates2016, CancerRates2017, CancerRates2018, CancerRates2019, CancerRates2020, CancerRates2021, CancerRates2022)
#CancerRatesLung <- CancerRates %>% filter(diseaseSite == "Lung")

#Step 2: Generate Map
#ggplot(CancerRatesLung) + geom_sf(mapping=aes(fill = rate_per_100k)) + scale_fill_viridis_c(name = "Lung Cancer Deaths/100k residents",limits = c(0, 50) + theme_void() + labs(title= "Lung Cancer Deaths/100k residents, 2013 - 2022: {current_frame}") + transition_manual(ddodyear) 






The difference between the geographic areas’ average mortality rates for each type of cancer was compared with a one way ANOVA. If significant differences were indicated at an alpha level of 0.05, post-hoc pairwise comparisons were done using Tukey’s Honest Significant Differences test.


Code
#oneWayAnovaLung <- aov(CancerRatesLung$rate_per_100k ~ CancerRatesLung$pumaCode)
#summary(oneWayAnovaLung)
#TukeyHSD(oneWayAnovaLung, conf.level = .95)

title: Research Goal
text:
Research Question: “How do the top 3 types of cancer death vary by geographic area (public use microdata area) over the past 10 years?”
This research could be used to create community health policies and programs that target populations with high cancer mortality rates.

Our research question investigates how the mortality rates of the three most prevalent cancer types vary by geographic area over the past ten years. We used the Census Bureau’s determination of Public Use Microdata Areas to define our distinct geographic areas in Multnomah County. This analysis could be used to inform local public health interventions such as a program providing early detection screenings in an area with a high cancer mortality rate. Findings could also be useful in future investigations of potential environmental hazards like pollution or chemical exposure in specific areas. Addressing inequities in healthcare quality and access based on geographic location is another potential application of this research.

title: Research Goal
text:
Research Question: “How do the top 3 types of cancer death vary by geographic area (public use microdata area) over the past 10 years?”
This research could be used to create community health policies and programs that target populations with high cancer mortality rates.

Our research question investigates how the mortality rates of the three most prevalent cancer types vary by geographic area over the past ten years. We used the Census Bureau’s determination of Public Use Microdata Areas to define our distinct geographic areas in Multnomah County. This analysis could be used to inform local public health interventions such as a program providing early detection screenings in an area with a high cancer mortality rate. Findings could also be useful in future investigations of potential environmental hazards like pollution or chemical exposure in specific areas. Addressing inequities in healthcare quality and access based on geographic location is another potential application of this research.

title: Conclusion
text:
East Portland has the highest average mortality rate across all studied years compared to all regions of Multnomah County, with Northwest and Southwest Portland possessing lower average cancer mortality rates than other studied regions.
A person’s residency in any location in Portland is highly correlated with a number of social determinants, suggesting these social determinants drive cancer mortality rather than environmental factors.
Further research into the association between cancer mortality and demographic identities may establish a stronger causal relationship than was present in our dataset.

We found that there is a significant difference in the rates of lung cancer mortality between different geographic areas of Multnomah County. Specifically, there was a trend of higher rates in Eastern areas and lower rates in Northern areas. To add context to this trend it is important to note that Northwest Portland has undergone rapid gentrification and is now very affluent whereas East Portland is home to more underserved communities who face inequities and barriers as a consequence. This suggests that the disparity in lung cancer deaths may be influenced by social determinants of health more than physical environmental hazards.
Looking at research on the association between lung cancer and demographic factors such as income, education, race, gender, and smoking habits in conjunction with census population data can further illuminate the spatial distribution of mortality rates. Our study did not find significant differences in the rates of breast or pancreatic cancer mortality among different geographic areas. Future research may uncover different results by addressing and correcting some of the limitations of this study such as missing geographic data and lack of gender distinction in breast cancer rate calculation.
